Summary: News - The C.B. Defense Cabinet: *Soruka Spokesperson:* *Good news from Saban Children's Hospital in Soruka* *7-year-old Amina Alhusani was hit in the head by shrapnel from an Iranian missile that was intercepted about 4 months ago in the Arad area. She was taken to Soroka in critical condition and was released today for rehabilitation*. Amina was referred to the trauma room in Soroka with a severe and complex head injury... Photo: Soroka

*Soruka Spokesperson:**Good news from Saban Children's Hospital in Soruka**7-year-old Amina Alhusani was hit in the head by shrapnel from an Iranian missile that was intercepted about 4 months ago in the Arad area. She was referred to Soroka in critical condition and was released today for rehabilitation*. Amina was referred to the trauma room in Soroka with a severe and complex head injury
Published (Pacific Time): when her life was in real danger. A multi-professional team stabilized her condition
Link: and she was rushed to urgent neurosurgery to save her life. Due to her severe injury
column5: she later had to undergo a series of neurosurgical operations in collaboration with other departments at the medical center. Amina was hospitalized for about two months in the pediatric intensive care unit at Saban Children's Hospital
column6: and was sedated and ventilated for a long time
column7: with a multi-professional team treating her throughout and fighting for her life: neurosurgery teams children
column10: plastic surgery and children's wards B and children's surgery
column11: and the health professions teams of physical therapy
column13: communication clinicians and social services. After a long hospitalization in children's intensive care and after her condition improved and she regained consciousness
column14: Amina was transferred to continue treatment in the children's department At Saban Children's Hospital.* Dr. Miki Gidon
column15: director of pediatric neurosurgery in Soroka
column16: and who operated on Amina during her long hospitalization:* 'Amina's head injury was severe
column17: complex and shocking. At the same time
column18: there was no doubt that we would fight for her life and to our great joy
column19: and with the efforts of all the teams we succeeded in our mission. To see Amina today fully conscious as she communicates
column20: smiles and is ready for the next stage of her rehabilitation
column21: fills our hearts with hope and strengthens our hands. From a personal point of view
column22: as someone who immigrated from Iran in her youth and now takes care of Amina who was harmed by the criminal Iranian attack
column23: this is about closing a circle.*Dr. Tzachi Lazar
column24: The director of the pediatric intensive care unit at Saban Children's Hospital in Soroka*: 'When Amina was admitted to the unit that Saturday night
column25: it was hard to believe that the small and fragile girl actually survived her severe injury. Much thanks to the multi-professional team that treated her with great dedication and professionalism
column26: but mostly thanks to Amina's strength
column27: her desire to live and recover
column29: who never left her bed during the long and difficult days of hospitalization. We were privileged to see Amina recover and get stronger and reach the day she moves to a rehabilitation setting. Amina
column30: whose injury was so severe that it was highly doubtful whether she would survive it
column31: taught us what a war for life is. Her mother
column32: father and brother who did not give up
column33: stayed with her day and night and continued to talk
column34: hug and demand that she get better - they got to have Amina back. I feel great pride in being part of Soroka's multi-professional team that contributed greatly to Amina's recovery and to her embarking on a new path of rehabilitation. All of us in the pediatric intensive care unit wish her and her family members good health and success in the future.
